channel.title: Networks on Functionally Defined
channel.description: Recent content in Networks on Functionally Defined

item.title: Interactive clothing networks
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(igraph) library(threejs) library(lubridate) library(stringr) library(reshape2) library(htmlwidgets) summer <- read_csv("/Users/allenchang/Desktop/functionally_defined/data/summer.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## Day = col_character(), ## Article = col_character(), ## Maker = col_character() ## ) fw <- read_csv("/Users/allenchang/Desktop/functionally_defined/data/fallwinter.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## Day = col_character(), ## Article = col_character(), ## Maker = col_character(), ## Color1 = col_character(), ## Color2 = col_character(), ## Month = col_character() ## ) fw <- fw %>% select(1:3) clothes_df <- rbind(summer, fw) clothes_df$Day <- mdy(clothes_df$Day) clothes_df <- clothes_df %>% mutate(maker_up = toupper(Maker)) %>% select(Day, maker_up) %>% filter(!

item.title: Network analysis of my daily clothing choices
item.description: This is a continuation of my previous analysis on tracking preferences in clothing choices (part 1 is here). The inspiration for this post came about after re-reading David Robinsonâ€™s network analysis of the movie love actually and realizing that a similar approach could be applied to my sparse network of clothing choices. I found additional help by working through the Network Analysis course on Datacamp. As per usual, these were the packages used.
